Headline.Para: Malaysia Struggles to Try Kim Jong Nam Slaying Without the Chief Suspect: North Korea; Prosecutors have yet to identify clear motive for the two women who claim they were duped into the killing

Snippet.Para: SHAH ALAM, Malaysia—Six months into the trial of two women accused of murdering the half-brother of North Korea's leader, prosecutors have yet to establish a clear motive—raising the prospect no one will be convicted.

Headline.Para: Malaysia Struggles to Try Kim Jong Nam Slaying Without the Chief Suspect: North Korea; Prosecutors have yet to identify clear motive for the two women who claim they were duped into the killing

LeadPara.Para: SHAH ALAM, Malaysia—Six months into the trial of two women accused of murdering the half-brother of North Korea's leader, prosecutors have yet to establish a clear motive—raising the prospect no one will be convicted.
The chief investigator had to defend his case Thursday against an increasingly glaring weakness—the absence of the main North Korean suspects, who escaped in the hours after the killing.

TailParas.Para: Wan Azirul Nizam Che Wan Aziz has become the face of a beleaguered prosecution struggling to identify a motive for the only suspects arrested. The women claim they were aspiring actresses manipulated into murdering Kim Jong Nam on Feb. 13 last year at Malaysia's main airport, as part of an intricate hoax.

The slaying added fuel to a U.S. drive to isolate North Korea and its leader, Kim Jong Un, to counter its worsening nuclear menace. It also put Malaysia in a difficult position, analysts said. Prosecuting the women risks undermining its relations with their countries, Indonesia and Vietnam, where they are seen as innocents. But failing to convict anyone would mean a crime that has attracted intense international attention goes unpunished.

"The fallout of not securing a conviction would tarnish Malaysia's reputation," said Hoo Chiew Ping, an international relations lecturer at the National University of Malaysia. Malaysia would be "unable to reach a satisfactory conclusion or explanation to South Korea," which says the ringleaders were North Korean intelligence operatives.

The chief investigator, Mr. Wan Azirul, said under cross-examination Thursday he didn't agree with defense counsel that the absence of the four North Koreans believed to have orchestrated the killing would prejudice the trial of the two women, who face the mandatory penalty of death by hanging if they are convicted of murder.

"In this case, they are the ones who did the killing," Mr. Wan Azirul said. He also said his investigation had come under pressure from his superiors, without elaborating. Malaysia's police chief didn't respond to a request for comment.

Mr. Kim's death exposed what had been, at that point, a close relationship between North Korea and Malaysia. It highlighted holes in Malaysia's enforcement of sanctions against the rogue regime. Malaysia suffered further embarrassment when Pyongyang held its diplomats hostage until Malaysia returned Mr. Kim's body and allowed two North Koreans, who were wanted for questioning, to leave. Malaysia downgraded ties with North Korea, which once included visa-free travel.

The defendants, Doan Thi Huong and Siti Aisyah, say they were tricked into killing Mr. Kim. They say they had made prank videos in the weeks before the attack, where they approached people in public places and wiped substances onto their faces. On the day Mr. Kim was killed, they were given a "smelly'" yellow oil that turned out to be VX, a nerve agent banned by the U.N. as a weapon of mass destruction.
Pyongyang protested accusations of involvement, ignored Interpol notices to detain four of its citizens and hasn't cooperated with the investigation.

Mr. Wan Azirul has come under fire from defense counsel for having a poor memory when questioned about Mr. Kim's presence in Malaysia or North Korean involvement in his death. He frequently failed to remember details or said he wasn't personally involved in some aspects, such as an inquiry into a mysterious meeting between Mr. Kim and an unknown Korean-American man on a resort island days before he died.

Mr. Wan Azirul denied any bias while acknowledging he made mistakes, though he didn't elaborate. On various occasions, he has complained of food poisoning or tiredness, spent long periods flicking through notes, or forgotten to bring reference materials altogether. During a hearing in January, the judge was visibly irritated after he failed to answer defense questions.

In October, the inspector became confused during questioning about pseudonyms used by the North Korean suspects, eventually apologizing and saying he was hungry. At another point, he said police had not investigated reports the defendants had conducted face-smear pranks in other countries.
Other details in the killing that haven't been explained by authorities include why Mr. Kim died carrying large quantities of cash and vials of antidote to the nerve agent that killed him.
The prosecution case will be delivered at intervals until at least early May. Judge Azmi Ariffin will then decide whether enough merit exists to proceed with the defense or to dismiss the charges.
Write to Jake Maxwell Watts at jake.watts@wsj.com and Yantoultra Ngui at yantoultra.ngui@wsj.com
